intro: Oxytropis bicolor, commonly known as the twinflower locoweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive blue or purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes, and it has a deep root system that helps it survive in arid conditions. Oxytropis bicolor is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock if ingested.
